item.title: AWS Cost Optimization - A Solution Architect's Guide
item.description: As cloud adoption continues to surge, managing AWS costs has become a critical skill for IT professionals. Here are key strategies I’ve found effective:

item.title: 5 Key Strategies to Effective Team Expectation Management
item.description: Over the years, I have learned that managing team expectations is crucial for the success of a project. Whether you’re deploying complex cloud solutions or leading any tech initiative, clear communication and alignment are key. Here are 5 strategies I’ve found effective in setting and managing expectations: 5 Key Strategies to Effective Team Expectation Management 1. Collaborate on Goals Involve your team in setting expectations to boost buy-in and motivation.

item.title: AWS Hidden Gems Mastering Athena, Config, and More
item.description: You’ve mastered EC2, S3 and VPC fundamentals. But to truly shine as an AWS Solutions Architect, you need to go beyond the basics. Let’s explore five “hidden gems” that will elevate your architecture game: 1. Athena Problem: Analyzing massive datasets stored in S3 can be a nightmare. Solution: Serverless query service for analyzing data directly in S3 using standard SQL. Impact: Enables real-time insights from your data without managing infrastructure. 2.

item.title: Unlocking Tribal Knowledge in the Business Campfire
item.description: Transforming Knowledge into Power: Why Sharing is Crucial in Business üåü In every organization, there is that one person who seems to have all the answers. Colleagues flock to them with issues, relying on their expertise to resolve challenges. While having such knowledgeable individuals can seem like a boon, it begs the question: is this reliance a strength or a potential risk for the company? The Double-Edged Sword of Expertise Experts within a company are invaluable, but dependence on them can inadvertently create bottlenecks and knowledge silos.

item.title: Effective Communication with Clients
item.description: Speaking to clients, knowing what to say, is not always easy. But it‚Äôs not always that simple. People learn how to talk to clients after working with serious ones. It‚Äôs like learning to swim in the deep end‚Äìyou might know the moves, but it feels different when the water‚Äôs over your head. We‚Äôll share tips on what not to say in front of clients. It‚Äôs all about making sure they trust you to handle the big stuff, without getting bogged down in words that might worry them or make things seem more complicated than they are.

item.title: Enhancing Security During Client Visits - Best Practices
item.description: Working with multiple clients across various settings has taught me the importance of robust security practices‚Äîand provided a few humorous yet educational moments when these rules were overlooked! Here‚Äôs how you can keep your reputation and data safe and avoid common pitfalls when working offsite: üîí Always Log Out: Ensure to log out from all devices when stepping away, even for brief moments. This simple action can protect sensitive information from unauthorized access or awful jokes from security guys üòÇ

item.title: Shifting to a cloud-native architecture
item.description: Shifting to a cloud-native architecture üåê is not just a trend‚Äîit’s a strategic move that can propel your applications to new heights in terms of flexibility, scalability, and performance. Today, we’re diving deep into the when, why, and how of making this crucial transition, with an eye on navigating the choices between cloud-native and traditional setups üöÄ. Let’s also tackle a common concern: the risk of vendor lock-in, and explore “safe” strategies to mitigate this issue.

item.title: 20+ incredible years of diving, head-first, into the ever-changing world of tech
item.description: üéàüéâ Big day today! üéâüéàNot only am I a year wiser, but I’m also celebrating over 20+ incredible years of diving, head-first, into the ever-changing world of tech. It’s been an absolute rollercoaster, and I wouldn’t have it any other way! My journey kicked off when ‘barebone servers’ were the cool kids on the block. Picture this: me, up to my elbows in hardware, setting up computers & servers from scratch.

item.title: GPT vs Gemini
item.description: As someone constantly exploring the forefront of technology, I’ve had opportunity to work closely with both solutions, diving deep into their capabilities by asking similar questions and observing the intriguingly different outcomes they offer. Gemini stands out for its speed and agility, providing quick and concise responses that are perfect for fast-paced environments. Its lightweight approach to answering queries is a breath of fresh air, making it an attractive option for those in need of swift insights.

item.title: Micromanagement The Silent Productivity Killer
item.description: I’ve learned a lot about teamwork and productivity throughout my career. One key lesson that stands out is the danger of micromanagement. Let me share some observations from my experience: Micromanagement: The Silent Productivity Killer In any team, we all want to achieve our best. But sometimes, our well-intentioned desire to help can actually get in the way. Micromanagement ‚Äì constantly overseeing and directing every detail of another person’s work ‚Äì can seriously drain productivity.

item.title: Consultants Are Like Avocados
item.description: Do you think consultants are useless? Think again! üôå My latest article is a Friday-perfect, lighthearted counterpoint to Steve Jobs’ grumbles about consultants. Get ready to change your mind! Steve Jobs on Consultants? Hold My Latte All right, let’s be honest. We all love Steve Jobs - the vision, the turtleneck, the whole deal. But when it came to consultants, the guy could be‚Ä¶well, a little harsh. He famously tossed shade, saying stuff like consultants don’t own solutions, and their expertise is all theoretical book-smarts.

item.title: Talking about AI and ML at Onet
item.description: I’m is explaining how Ringier Axel Springer Polska and Onet are innovating with #AI and #MachineLearning - e.g. to ensure the diversity in the media.

item.title: AWS Certified Solutions Architect - Associate
item.description: After a decade of working with AWS, I am thrilled to share that I have earned my first professional certificate as a Solution Architect. I am both surprised and humbled by this achievement. 23T0L60C6NE41F3G ( https://aws.amazon.com/verification )

item.title: SSL Certificate
item.description: I’ve got this client which is each year asking me to renew their SSl certificate. It‚Äôs EV, so it requires a little more paperwork, and a new lady from the office was helping with the process. After three weeks of pushing scans and talking with Indians, we finally got a certificate. I replaced the old one and sent an e-mail that it‚Äôs up and running. She asked me to send her a copy - I thought - it was a good point.

item.title: NodeMcu (ESP8266) water level monitor with a voltage sensor
item.description: This subject in the theory looks very easy. Just get NodeMcu board, plug sensor from the family of sensors (HY-SRF05, HC-SR04), some kind of voltage sensor and we are good to go. But you can get couple of unexpected issues here. Let‚Äôs start from the NodeMcu unit. It‚Äôs specific.

item.title: Arduino double relay keypad lock
item.description: I needed key-less way to open my garage door. Quite often I forgot my remote, so just need something easy to open them without remote. Because I have regular ‚Äúring type‚Äù opener (click and release to open door) needed something to ‚Äúclick‚Äù door for me based on something which I remember (not own ‚Äì remote / key / etc). Basic idea ‚Äì keypad + arduino + relay to click the button.

item.title: USB to TTL / Serial MacOS Mojave
item.description: Got a bunch of these little f*ckers and couldn‚Äôt make them to work with my Mojave fresh installation. Previously they were working, and now they are gone. I wasn‚Äôt sure what exactly I‚Äôve got. I just run Serial Detect to identify what model do I own: Then I googled driver for MacOS Mojave. Because original website: CP210x USB to UART Bridge VCP Drivers likes to file, I made a mirror on my server.

item.title: Quote - Get out of life what you deserve
item.description: ‚ÄúSpend each day trying to be a little wiser than you were when you woke up. Day by day, and at the end of the day-if you live long enough-like most people, you will get out of life what you deserve.‚Äù ‚Äî‚ÄäCharlie Munger

item.description: ‚ÄúMost people never pick up the phone and call. Most people never ask. And that‚Äôs what separates, sometimes, the people that do things from the people that just dream about them. You gotta act and you gotta be willing to fail.‚Äù ‚Äî‚ÄäSteve Jobs

item.title: Another day another award‚Ä¶

item.title: GE Ecomagination Centre

item.title: USB to Serial for Mac OS X
item.description:
In this quick tutorial will show how to ‚Äútalk‚Äù quickly to Serial port on Mac OS X.

Mac OS X will automatically create a serial device, which can be found in /dev.

Start a terminal session and list all available serial (or tty) devices available.

item.title: How to create information kiosk using Chrome and touch screens
item.description:
While ago I was working in company called Imagination. I‚Äôve done some very cool projects while I was working there, and this is history off one of them.

Challenge

We were ask to create interactive solution to show case history of the oil company, for exhibition. Something really simple and inexpensive. We made information ‚Äúkiosks‚Äù where people could browse history of the company.

item.title: Quote - Leadership
item.description: Leadership is the art of getting someone else to do something you want done because he wants to do it. Dwight D. Eisenhower

item.title: Cheap Arduino clone DccEle ‚Äì DCcduino Uno
item.description: Recently I bought very cheaply Arduino UNO Clone called DccEle ‚Äì DCcduino UNO. Be default It wasn‚Äôt recognized by my Mac OS. After a quick google search, I found this article ¬†which pointed me to proper drivers.

item.title: From book The Clean Coder: A Code of Conduct for Professional Programmers

item.title: Simplest Arduino Clock With 7-digit segment display
item.description:
From time to time, I‚Äôm also working on less ‚Äúweb‚Äù related project. This time, a wanted to play a bit with Arduino platform. The task was pretty simple ‚Äì to build a clock. Yes ‚Äì these days, we don‚Äôt have enough time measuring devices like mobiles, microwaves, computers ‚Äì I wanted to build another one.

It was my first Arduino project so the task wasn‚Äôt ¬†as easy as I expected. In the theory, we need only pass time & data from RTC to 7-Segment Display. Simple isn‚Äôt it? I found plenty of tutorials, had so many small issues like ‚Äì digits wasn‚Äôt displayed correctly (mixed cables). I could only display one digit at the time in given position or ‚Äì same digits everywhere (multiplexing). I couldn‚Äôt find shift register in my stock, so wanted to use whatever I already had.
